thread.title: Excitement building in Irish camp - O'Connell
thread.title_full: Excitement building in Irish camp - O'Connell

title: Excitement building in Irish camp - O'Connell
text:
Excitement building in Irish camp - O'Connell Saturday, October 03, 2015 - 01:44 
Ireland captain Paul O'Connell says excitement is building in the Irish camp as the Rugby World Cup goes on. ▲ Hide Transcript ▶ View Transcript 
SENDING WITH FULL SCRIPT SHOWS: LONDON, ENGLAND, UK (OCTOBER 3, 2015) (REUTERS - FOR EDITORIAL USE ONLY) 1. OLYMPIC STADIUM 2. FLOODLIGHTS 3. IRELAND CAPTAIN PAUL O'CONNELL WALKING OUT OF TUNNEL 4. LOW SHOT OF IRELAND PLAYERS WALKING OUT OF TUNNEL 5. VARIOUS OF IRELAND PLAYERS TRAINING 6. O'CONNELL AT TRAINING 7. VARIOUS OF FLY HALF JONATHAN SEXTON AT TRAINING 8. O'CONNELL AND ASSISTANT COACH LES KISS WALK INTO NEWS CONFERENCE 9. SOUNDBITE (English) IRELAND CAPTAIN, PAUL O'CONNELL, SAYING: "Every game is a real tight game, every game has been a real tight game and it has built the excitement levels. I can't remember a World Cup before where as a team or as a group where we have sat around on couches and watched the games and that has built the excitement. It is the third week in it for us now and definitely there is a feeling of knockout rugby for us this week and opponents we are really familiar with and they are really familiar with us." STORY: Ireland skipper Paul O'Connell says things will get tougher as his side reach the business end of their Rugby World Cup. After straightforward wins in their first two matches against Romania and Canada, Ireland's remaining Pool D fixtures are distinctly tougher. First they take on fellow Six Nations foes Italy on Sunday (October 4) at the Olympic stadium in London, then they face France in a week's time. Should Ireland win both matches they will avoid a potential quarter final with defending champions New Zealand. But if they slip up they will have to face the All Blacks - or even worse, find themselves on the plane home. "Every game is a real tight game, every game has been a real tight game and it has built the excitement levels," O'Connell told reporters at a pre match news conference for the Italy match on Saturday. "I can't remember a World Cup before where as a team or as a group where we have sat around on couches and watched the games and that has built the excitement. It is the third week in it for us now and definitely there is a feeling of knockout rugby for us this week and opponents we are really familiar with and they are really familiar with us." Although Italy will start as underdogs, they did beat Ireland in the Six Nations two years ago - one of just four victories they have had over the men from the Emerald Isle against 20 defeats.
